text:

Anyone with past experience with this? Or knows the models of rentals that have more room than others? We are looking at the Fiat 500L but not sure that will be big enough. Appreciate any advice and suggestions!

You’re going elsewhere besides just Tuscany? Take the trene to Pompeii one day, absolutely the most interesting place I’ve ever seen. Go to the main train station in Naples, transfer to the local train, it stops roughly 20 minutes later right at the gate to Pompeii! I forget the train name/line, however if you’re seriously interested I’m happy to look it up for you.

Go to the Acacamia museum, Pont a Vechico, Uficci art gallery! I have not spelt them properly, but just get lost in Firenze! You will find amazing architecture, markets. Catch a bus to San Giminarno, Sienna! I had an apartment in Firenze for 3 months, and the architecture, food, culture is and respect for the locals is stunning!
Santa Croaca , the Duomo in Firenze is a must. Try and catch public transport as much as possible.
Buy an Italian/
English dictionary, which will be a great help.
Look up always, so you get your bearings! Have fun and enjoy 😉

I stayed in a Pension near the Duomo and walked and walked everywhere getting lost is a must!
But I fear 5 days is not enough time! One needs to slow down and pace your days, without rushing! 🙏

text:
Hello everyone
Looking for a place to stay in Ischia. I temporarily booked Hotel Albatros.
Has anyone stayed there?
I’m looking for a clean, well air conditioned & close to the beach for a family of 5.
We have 4 days to see Rome- any suggestions to beat the heat and walking too much. Is there a suggestion regarding a private car tour for 1 day? This was the only time of year we could all go.
Any tips on getting seats together on Economy flights with Delta and IITA airlines? Does getting there early help? We tried to upgrade and told us we could not.

comments.comment_text: Ask at airport or ask someone to switch once of flight.

Go to the gate podium when the attend shows up and ask what the possibility is to be seated together. I have done it numerous times with delta. Even when I have had no seat assignment until I get to the gate.
Only once did they say they could not. And often when I have no seat assigned they put us in the emergency door row which tends to have more leg room.
Don't expect anyone already seated to move for you unless it's to a better seat.
Usually you can pay an extra fee to pick your seats. Have you checked for that option on their website?
Did you purchase “Basic Economy” tickets on Delta? If so, your seats will be assigned at check in. The earlier you check in, the better.

Those are good months. We were there in May this year and it was a bit cool and rainy, but I have been in May when it has been lovely and warm. So it can be different year to year. April, May, September and October are all good months.

We are doing Rome, positano Florence in 9/10 days (losing one with overnight travel). Just picked 3 places
Take your time, allow time to do nothing, don't try to do too much. Everywhere is very busy, so allow time to enjoy rather than rushing to the next place.

4-Rome
3-Florence/
Siena
2-Como

Losing too much time to travel if you include Amalfi Coast.

Milan 2 days

We only spent half a day in positano - overrated in my opinion (so is Capri) found sorrento a better base.
Florence
Sorrento
Rome

Skip Positano. Three days in Rome, 3 days in Florence with desired day trips (perhaps Cinque Terre or elsewhere in Liguria instead of Positano) and 3 days not just Lake Como but Lake Maggiore as well. Gorgeous!
Book a room at florence for the entire trip. Then do day trips to each from florence, or even staybover night if you want while still keeping the florence home base.
Factor in travel time between towns- Sorrento- to Rome- to Florence.

I’d personally recommend visiting Lake Garda instead of Como! I feel like there’s more to do and see personally🤍 (I’ve just recently visited the North of the Lake as well as the south). You can also visit Verona in 30 minutes from Garda, or Venice in about 1.5 hours. Also with Lake Garda/Como you’d need to decide which area of the lake you want to stay in! For Como for example I’ve heard it’s better to stay in Bellagio or Varenna.

It depends on what YOU want to see and do though because you could easily spend all those 9 days in Rome exploring the whole city and the areas beyond (using Rome as your base). If you want to truly experience the city, I’d recommend at least 4 days there.

Depending on how much you want to see/do in Florence, you can even take a day trip there from Rome - the fast trains can take only 1.5 hours to get there.

Whilst I’ve not been to Positano I’ve heard it can be very expensive/it’s overrated (though again I can’t properly comment!) I have been to Salerno in the south though and it was beautiful and very easy to make day trips to the Amalfi Coast and areas along there (also Pompeii if you’re interested in that).

Instead of Positano - if you wanted to enjoy the sea/scenic locations, there’s a beautiful island just off Rome called Monte Argentario which is stunning, and then there’s also plenty of beautiful beaches along the Ligurian coast such as Portofino so maybe have a look at there! It’s also more North so will be easier to get to from Florence/head to Como or other places you want to visit.

If I was to create an itinery based off what I’ve just said and what you want to see I’d suggest:

4 days Rome (including a day trip to Florence)
2 days at the Ligurian coast (staying in a beach town/in or near Portofino)
3 days in Lake Garda (including maybe a day trip to Verona if that’s what you were interested in).

Like I said before, it depends what YOU want to do! What are you interested in most and want to see? Are you okay travelling sometimes 2 hour+ journeys every other day to get to the next place? Maybe do a little more research into the areas you’re interested in and see what you think🥰

Feel free to drop me a DM with any questions, I’ve been to Italy a good amount of times now/travelled through the country and love the country so I’m more than happy to talk about it! (As you can probably tell😂)

Hope this helps a lil!✨
In my opinion is too much! 3 days in Rome ,2 days Florence (1 Florence and day trip to Siena) , 1 day Bologna , 2day Venezia

You could do it, but I think you're trying to see too much in 9/10 days... don't forget you have to travel place to place, find your accomodations, check in, eat, and then sightsee...for 10 days I'd say spend 3 days in Rome and then Florence 3 days then Venice 2-3 days .. Imho to really experience Italy, slow travel is best, or it all becomes a blur and you don't get the "feel" of anywhere you've been...and more than the sights which are truly spectacular, it's the "feel" that will make you wanting to go back again and again ...for longer & longer trips

This is for Italy

Yes! I think they're better than the two prong ones, as the latter can sometimes be loose in some of the sockets (for example those on trains) and fall out (they'd still work, you just have to be more careful). I recently traveled for 6 weeks all over Italy with a 3 prong adapter like this and it worked everywhere. I had a 2 prong one just in case, but never had to use it.
The only disadvantage is that you wouldn't be able to use it in other European countries (whereas the 2 prong one you could use in most). But if you're going only to Italy, you're good.

The majority of the appliances in Italy have three prongs, because of the earthing system (central pin), although a few are exempted. In theory, all homes in italy should have electrical sockets with three holes (because of the earthing system), but not all do. So the three-pronged adaptors in theory should be the only ones used because the law requires buildings to have the earthing system, but the two-pronged ones are also used (and maybe are even more common) because they will work in every home, including the ones that haven't updated their electrical system yet.

The condo where I lived for 3 years had 2 different sized 3 prong outlets. (The prongs themselves were fat or skinny) I had adapters to from fat to skinny and skinny to fat.

text: Recommendation for early morning coffee / breakfast before hitting the 9am Colosseum tour?

Heading to Sorrento tomorrow from Rome with a stop in Pompeii. With the temperature being over 100 degrees, just wondering if you think we’ll still enjoy Pompeii if we don’t have a tour guide? Just not sure some of our family members can take 2 to 3 hours in this hot weather without any shade.

comments.comment_text:
I was there today from 10am to 2pm and there is shade if you go before noon. We made plenty of stops along the way, but spent 4h total there. There are multiple water fountains on site. I highly recommend getting a tour guide though, there was not many signs/
descriptions of the artefacts.

I would recommend a guide. We had a guide for about the first 2 hours and had a great experience, as soon as the tour was over we were lost on our own. You can get them at the gate, a private guide was 150
Thoughts on tour guide vs Rick Steve's audio guide?

We went to Pompeii yesterday got there 9am skip the line, went to the back of Pompeii and worked our way back towards the exit much less crowded doing it that way - took 2-3.5 hours and we are all reasonably fit, we just stayed on the shade side ! Plenty of water fountains to refill your bottle, did it ourselves just followed the map we had a hand held audio guide for info
There was a breeze yesterday
Also I hate guided tours so can’t comment on that side !
Yes!
Skip Pompeii got heat exhaustion and hotel summoned a Dr. Lost three days . Was also disappointed stay in a hotel in Sorrento by the pool.

We were told by Italian relatives that took us that we should latch on to a group with an English-speakin
g guide to save money and have a more interesting visit. We did this part of the time. We mostly walked around on our own.
We did 1230-230 without a tour guide earlier this month and it was hot but it was fine and still enjoyable. Even maps has some of the bigger buildings listed on what they are!
Honestly, you really need someone knowledgeable to help you understand what you’re seeing.
I’m not sure I’d go to Pompeii even with a tour guide if the temp is 100. Very little shade.
Too hot
I would not go there in this kind of heat.

If you have family members you are concerned about, I would skip it. It’s not an easy walk, the rock and stone makes everything hotter, and there’s very little shade. There are water and snack vendors all over the street when you leave, but no where to sit and rest. You don’t t want to have someone fall ill from the heat, or physically fall down in there. 😔

I noticed the elders in Spain/
Andalucía (114F) use umbrellas for shade, I’m thinking of bringing one myself.

Couldn’t pay me to go to Pompei, even in pleasant weather conditions…tooo
o boring for me
Pompeii is very hot and dusty at the best of times, +40c would be a killer.
Can you go very early?
I didn’t enjoy Pompeii but I LOVED Ravello, Positano and a beach day at Sorrento
Honestly it will be brutal. Pompeii is incredible but…. Not in this heat

Go early, bring water and an umbrella.
Personally I wouldn’t do it as a stop over. Travel days can be tiring enough!
Go another morning from Sorrento, take the train and get as soon as it opens in the morning.

I absolutely loved it and spent about 5 hours wandering around etc. However this was in April and even though it was raining when we left Sorrento it was sunny and very warm at Pompeii.
It’s brutal
Take your time take lots of water- stop and rest when overheating. Go early as possible! Don’t miss the opportunity to see this wonder!
Bring umbrellas. I would hire a guide to make the most of your experience in the shortest amount of time. It will get you out of the heat sooner without feeling like you missed out.
I would not do it given the temperatures . I’ve been there and there really isn’t any shade . It’s hot in normal summer temperatures…. Not a great time to visit Pompeii
Avoid Pompeii in the heat!
Better off without a tour guide I think...if you're feeling overheated at least you can stop and take your time.

Umbrellas and water no matter what you do. Buy a cute small Umbrella (tj maxx has them) to keep in your luggage and a reusable waterbottle. Maybe even take a washcloth to keep damp for the back of your neck should you start to feel off

We were in Pompeii 3 weeks ago. It was hot and no shade. I had a cooling towel which helped and an umbrella which was a hassle. The restaurant on the grounds charged €10 each just to sit even though we bought lunch.
We did this two days ago. Fans helped. There is a little shade. We did have a guide and took the two hours. I had an umbrella to help shield some of the Sun.

We were there just 4 days ago ! It was incredibly hot , there is next to no shade as you walk around . We went on a small group tour lead by an archaeologist (ASKOS tours) , he was very good and sensitive to the extreme heat conditions so dog us to the best , most significant areas , I think we did cut it a little short due the conditions. We went on in the afternoon and did the Herculaneum, it was next level hotter ! We added in a driver to get us from Naples to Pompeii and then onto Herculaneum and back to Naples , air conditioned car shared with 6 other people , well worth the extra rather than going by train !

We are now in Sorrento and it’s still hot , but you have the sea to cool down in 😃

Took bus to Positano this morning from Sorrento, great bus ride ! Then ferry back to Sorrento! Positano was crazy busy, and super hot 🥵🔥
It's all rock, and stone without any shade....so please take water and an umbrella. I'm sure the heat will bounce off the stone too..
Pompeii is so so hot! I would highly recommend a tour guide not that it makes it any cooler. Water water and wet towels to get you through
Go early! We were there around 10 am and you could still hide in the shade a bit :)
We went 2 weeks ago and while there is not much shade, there was a breeze. I suggest that you bring an umbrella, which can provide some shade, and water. We went without a guide and spent about 3h.

Very little shade in Pompeii, we went a few years ago, it was around 90 degrees that day and it was hard going,

Wear a hat , take an umbrella and keep hydrated.

I used wet towels a week ago and froze fruit boxes! I took fans but they weren’t overly useful. If you self guid make sure you get the right map. We bought a book and map from someone outside the site and the map wasn’t at all helpful! There is shade. There are buildings where you can be inside and buildings where you can find shade.
There is also a kiosk and toilet in the main square where you can re-wet your towels. Maybe go, see it and if you leave straight away so be it! Taxi home though as waiting for the bus was the worst part!
It will be so hot, go early 🌻
Are you intent on going to Pompeii, because there also is Herculaneum which is smaller but better preserved. A guide does help you figure out what it is you are looking at.

Skip Pompeii, recommend visiting The Palace at Caserta. 👑
Arrive early and rent electric bikes 🏍️ to ride the grounds.

Go early, bring water and umbrellas. We went without a tour guide in June and we regretted it. Even with the audio guide, we ended up wandering around and missing pieces.

Honestly, unless your group is set on seeing Pompeii, I'd probably skip it in this heat.

I went last week with my 2 teenagers, one was very interested in Pompeii as she studies classics, the other teen not so much. We had Rick Steve's audio guide downloaded, got there for 9.30, it was hot, by 11.30 we stopped in the cafe for a break, no ac in there but it was cooler, left the uninterested teen in there and went back out to finish our own tour. Its manageable but be prepared, its very hot and not a lot of shade.

Just there a few days ago!! Super hot, but we were there in the morning and there was some shade that the tour guide stopped in to talk to us- our whole family loved it!! For sure I’d say go!

(One of the shops outside was selling mostly frozen water bottles…. I loved having one! Melted fully about 1/2 hour into the tour, but the cold water was great!!)
A tour guide would be awesome- but not in this heat. If you can organize to be at the entrance at 9 am then it might work. The heat is unrelenting right now.
Download Rick Steves Audio Guide. You don’t need a tour guide. Wear hat and keep hydrated

Pompeii is wonderful, but even in regular summer weather it can be hot because not very much is covered. People normally spend 2-3 hours, so in this heat, I might recommend against it for health reasons.

text:
RENT A CAR IN ITALY - TOP TRAVEL TIPS :
Most visitors to Italy pick up their rental cars right at the airport. Rome Fiumicino, Milan Malpensa, and Venice Marco Polo are not only the country's busiest airports but also its main car rental hubs. Picking up and dropping off a rental car right at the airport is usually the cheapest option
Choosing the right rental car supplier is really important. Interrent, Enterprise, and National are the three highest-rated car rental companies in Italy.
Renting a vehicle for a longer period usually brings the daily price down significantly. A five-day trip might be only slightly more expensive than a three-day trip because of this. If you can, consider exploring Italy for at least a week!
Familiarize yourself with the rental conditions such as the mileage and fuel policies before booking a car!
Learn about the traffic rules and speed limits before your trip — they might be different than in your country!
If you plan to drive in the Alps in winter, you might need snow chains — ask your rental car supplier about them.
Book here for the best price: https://www.discovercars.com/?a_aid=NextStop-Italy

text: We are travelling to Italy in September and I am wondering if it’s better to take the bus or the train when moving locations? When I look at the train from Rome to Ortona it is longer and more expensive than the bus. Any reason for this? What are peoples preferences? TIA!

comments.comment_text: Either works well, so choose the fastest route (but always look at the route). Note that the bus route on Rome to Rio shows bus to Pescara then a change to a train to Ortona. In this case I would take the train, even though that also has a change of trains in Pescara. At least you are at the train station to make the change. Trains usually are best between popular destinations, but Ortona is a bit off the beaten path.

Don't like bus drivers...train
is better

Definitely I would choose the train…
And one of the reasons is that along the ride you will see so much of the beauty of Italy👌
If a train doesn’t go there take a bus.
Definitely train
Train

We always do the train. I haven't found it to be more expensive though. It's a long train ride though so it's about 40E to get to Foggia via Italo and then 25E to get to Ortona via Trenitalia. So 65E. Agree that you will see some gorgeous countryside. About 6 hours.
Thanks all! We booked the train 😊

text: I am not checking a bag for my trip to Italy in September, but I want to bring home wine, limoncello and olive oil. Any suggestions for best, cheapest way to do this. Thanks

comments.comment_text: Maybe purchase at a duty free shop at the airport?

I’ve had wineries ship my stuff back. They have great packing materials and the shipping co is responsible. It runs about 6-10 per bottle. Cheaper being a full 12 case on a per bottle basis.
Since usually buy 12-24 per trip it would be hard to check.
Oil and limoncello you’ll have to check since the liquid can’t go into a carryon. Unless you buy it at duty free and the airport or get the merchant to ship to you.
In the FCO airport before you are going home the duty free bag is sealed and I do believe they won’t question that as soon as you arrive in the US as long as you keep it sealed
Ship your clothing home and pack the gifts in your suitcase. Super easy to send just clothing. My daughter sent two large bags and it was about $80. I’m doing that next time!!
Most of the Italian wine shops deliver everything you need
Duty free!
While not the cheapest, we always have the shops ship our wines and such back. We only do carry-on luggage anymore, and that works best for us.
Would it not be cheaper to just pack it in your suitcase and check your bag?
Could you check in 10 kg not to carry on iv checked in 20 kg bag as I’m getting all those aswell
Mail it at Mailboxes Etc.

I am going in September and plan on bringing a carry-on for clothing. Our airfare includes a free checked bag. So I am going to check an empty suitcase on the way there and bring all my goodies home in it on the way back.￼
We have everything shipped by the merchant. It arrives at your door, no hassles at customs and you don’t have to lug it around. Happy husband too as he would be the one carrying it!

If you're flying from FCO T1 or MXP T1 you can take liquids in your hand luggage wit6no restrictions. Of course you need to check the stopover location if your flight is not direct

You can always buy a piece of inexpensive luggage while there for souvenirs and check that bag on the way home!

text:
Hi all!
So we are taking a driving trip through northern Italy. I really want to stop in Venice for a couple days, but how does that work with a car? I’d just like to have logistics worked out beforehand….
Thank you!

comments.comment_text: You park on the mainland and take a boat over. Not too pricey.
We stayed in Mestre and caught the train in.

You can leave your car at Tronchetto parking, on the main land. Then you can take a vaporetto o metromover and then walk to your hotel. Very convenient. Please consider sleeping in Venice, not in Mestre or surroundings, since by night Venice is pure magic.
There is a huge car park right next to the train station.

We parked at Garage Piazzale Roma which is about as close to the city centre as you can get. It's also where many of the rental car companies are. From there it's a very short walk to the Vaporetto and water taxis etc.

Hi, maybe you can book a hotel in Mogliano Veneto or also in Treviso and then go by train to Venice, you take only 20 or 30 minutes and you have trains around every 30 minutes. Treviso worth a stop also for a walk specially in the evening. it's called like a small Venice also..🙂
Parking lot

We are just back and the tronchetti parking is very easy to park and find. Short walk round the corner to where the boats are. We got a private boat back to the car down the grand canal and the kids loved it!

I’m from Perth and go every year to Italy , myself I would as I show friends around. I try not to back track. Just be aware the small towns often close Saturday afternoons if it is not peak season . Rome I stay in a 3 star hotel near the termini called Hotel Nord Nuova & in Florence love this area called Santo Spirito in airb&b about a 15 minute walk into city but so much to see cafe,shops,bars
along the way near Pitti place over Ponto Vecchio. I go either February (winter) & October still beautiful weather most times enjoy 🌻

oy

We are Australian and just home after a month in Italy. We went to Rome for three nights, then down to Sorrento by train and private car from Naples, back to Naples from Sorrento by ferry, stayed in Naples for five nights (loved Naples !) The train goes from Naples to Venice (a bit over five hours), then make your way back to Rome via Como etc or make your way to Venice then fly back to connect to your flight home.
So many beautiful day trips into Tuscany from Lucca! We stayed in a tiny village 40 minutes from Lucca for ten days and it wasn’t long enough.

I think that sounds fine but I'd try to add another night in the Cinque Terre as you really need a full day to see the villages (not sure if you're doing any walks), another day to venture to Portofino and another day to just wander around. People have differing opinions about itineraries and where to stay and when I read comments I often think they're not factoring in travel time and potential delays (just my opinion). I'd suggest Varenna on Lake Como as it's easy to get to/from and is a good base. Plenty of people say skip Milan and if that means spending more time in the CT you could take it off your itinerary but it's a nice city with some great attractions. If pressed for time you could maybe have one night there (depending on arrival time). I haven't been to Naples so can't comment but 5 nights in Sorrento will give you plenty of time to explore the Amalfi Coast/Capri. Many are saying too many nights in Lucca but it would be a good base to explore Tuscany if you have a car. I've been to Tuscany many times and there's so many small towns to spend time in. Enjoy your planning.

Having just returned from our latest adventure, and having spent two nights in Milan to fly home to Melbourne, I would suggest skipping Milan altogether. I felt we wasted two days 🥺
We had 3nts in Venice, which I felt was perfect, 4nts in Bellagio (Lake Como) also perfect, and then headed down into a Puglia for 8nts. We have stayed in CT a few times - my #1 fave🙌🥰 - so keep that (I recommend Vernazza as the prettiest, but if you want a bigger beach stay in Monterosso). That’s a lot of nights in Lucca… I would be more inclined to stay in Firenze and do a day trip to Lucca, even an overnight (it is very pretty at night), and then you can do another day trip to another Tuscan town during that time. I assume you’re not staying in Naples, just passing through to Sorrento? Make sure you do a day trip to Capri, and if the weather allows visit the Blue Grotto!

Looks like a great trip! I think way too much time in Lucca and would consider Florence or Siena as your base while you explore Tuscany. Or Puglia another region to consider. Possibly look into agriturismos. Sorrento makes sense as long as you are doing day trips to Amalfi and I would skip Naples. Same with Milan. It’s a business city and not one to linger with so many other beautiful destinations to see.

text:
Ciao a tutti!

We are in Italy right now and I had a lot of requests in a previous post for info on our accommodation. To ensure my response doesn’t get lost (there were loads of comments) I thought I’d drop it in a new post.

Hope this helps.

BTW, it’s hot 🥵 (and before the comments start, we knew exactly what we were coming into) our current Airbnb had a pool 🏊🏻‍♀️ 👌🏻

*****************************************
Hi All, to everyone that asked for my recommendation for accommodation I will just post here. There were so many requests so hope that is ok.

Venice - we stayed on the island. The Airbnb was beautiful and on the canal. We had to catch a waterbus across to the mainland, which was no problem but it was €9.50 each way. The villa had one double bedroom and 2 singles were in the living room, along with chairs and a table - it worked ok. There was one bathroom. It was a short walk to a co-op and restaurants. If you want a quiet stay, this is the place. Very clean and host was very helpful. Waterbus also takes you back to the train Termini. Eating was reasonably priced.

Calle delle erbe
Giudecca, Venice, 30133, Italy

Florence - we stayed at Plus Florence which is a hostel but we had a private room with 4 single beds and a huge private ensuite. It was about a 10 min walk to the main Termini. The buffet breakfast is cheap. Very close to the markets. A bit of a walk to the pointe vecchio but we stopped along the way for a drink etc. The pool gets busy and very popular with the 20ish year olds but they were no bother. We are a family of 4 and there were other families there.

Plus Florence
Via Santa Caterina D'Alessandria 15, Florence, 50129, Italy

Rome - we stayed in the Vatican area which was not our initial choice but our original accommodation was cancelled on us so we were left with whatever was available on our budget. This apartment is immaculate! 3 double rooms all with ensuites. Great air con. Short walk to the metro which made it very easy to get around. Many restaurants around the area but didn’t offer a great deal if you’re looking to shop. There were markets nearby which offered some cheap clothing. The apartment exceeded our expectations. Host was very easy to deal with.

Vatican Townhouse
Viale Giulio Cesare, Vaticano Prati , Rome, 00192, Italy

Hope that helps. Let me know if you have any other questions ☺️

I think “Grand hotel” is one of those terms that doesn’t have a specific, clearly defined meaning. And that can feel misleading sometimes.

It seems to me that a lot of old traditional hotels are called Grand Hotels, so that’s what I assume when I hear the name. I automatically substitute “old style” in my mind for the word Grand in a hotel’s name. I visualize an older, historic hotel that was probably top of the line once or architecturally
significant back when it was built. But one that may or may not need updating for current tastes. I think sometimes the best thing about a Grand Hotel might be the location or the view.

But that’s just me, so who knows? Maybe it really does mean something else that im
not aware of!
